STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980
August 8, 2025
Jennifer Shores
LIVINGSTON COUNTY DHHS
2300 E GRAND RIVER AVE. Suite 1
HOWELL, MI, 48843-7577
Re: License #: CP470201250
SI #: 2025SIC0000684
Dear Ms. Shores:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager, at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000684
Special Investigation Intake Date: May 12, 2025
License #: CP470201250
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling
Chief Administrator: Ahmad Sabbagh
Agency Name: LIVINGSTON COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 2300 E GRAND RIVER AVE STE 1
Suite 1
HOWELL, MI 48843-7577
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 11/19/2025
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
7/21/2025 1:00 PM Phone Interview
7/3/2025 10:00 AM Email Interview
7/1/2025 11:30 AM Documentation Other
6/25/2025 12:45 PM Documentation Documentation received or sent
6/10/2025 9:00 AM Documentation Documentation received or sent
6/4/2025 11:00 AM Phone Interview
6/4/2025 11:00 AM Phone Interview
5/28/2025 11:00 AM Documentation Documentation received or sent
1

5/23/2025 1:00 PM Phone Interview
5/22/2025 1:00 PM Video Conference Interview
5/13/2025 4:30 PM Email Interview
5/13/2025 4:00 PM Email Special Investigation Initiation
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Foster Parent alleged falsification of court reports and statements
by Livingston County DHHS.
Investigation Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed on 5/23/2025, via
telephone. FP reported she was being threatened that Youth A
and Youth B were going to be removed from her home because
she advocated against a dangerous decision. When asked where
this information came from, FP did not state who threatened her to
remove Youth A or Youth B from her care or where this
information came from.
FP reported and identified Chief Administrator in regard to writing
a court report that had falsified information. She did not state
when this report was written. FP reported she wrote a letter on
4/23/2025, addressing Guardian ad Litem (GAL), Department of
Health and Human Services (DHHS) attorney, Livingston County
Prosecutor, Community Mental Health (CMH) Therapist, DHHS
Program Manager and DHHS current Foster Care Worker (FCW)
and Supervisor of Youth A and Youth B’s case. FP reported she
wrote this letter because she felt this was defamation of her
character and false information had been submitted to the courts.
FP reported she formally addressed a series of deeply concerning
and factually incorrect claims that have been made about her care
for Youth A. FP reported specifically, it was stated she declined
multiple services for Youth A and this was unequivocally false.
When asked where this information came from, FP alluded to
nurses’ notes from Mott’s University of Michigan (UM) Hospital
2

that stated, the preference is for Youth A to get some sleep while
in “CES” and to be reevaluated the next morning. The writer (No
name provided) informed FP that Partial Hospitalization Program,
(PHP) would be unlikely to take Youth A due to his level of
behavioral dysregulation. FP was provided with nurse’s notes from
CMH and Mott’s UM Hospital. Please note, this was unable to be
provided for consultant review as this information would involve
HIPPA law.
FP continued to state the report claimed she refused services,
such as the Wraparound Program through CMH. However, this
decision was made based on direct guidance from the therapist at
CMH. FP reported she was advised that participation in
wraparound would restrict access to other CMH programs that
were more appropriate and beneficial for Youth A’s specific needs.
FP reported to suggest she declined services is not only
inaccurate, but it was also slanderous.
FP reported DHHS Attorney asserted that children were not safe
in her care and this contradiction was both harmful and absurd.
FP reported DHHS Attorney repeatedly made false and damaging
statements about her and her parenting skills. FP said this
information was in the Court Orders.
Please note, in review of the court orders, there were no
statements found that that presented defamation of FP’s
character.
Chief Administrator (CA) and Program Manager (PM) were
interviewed via TEAM on 5/22/2025. CA and PM reported there
were no court reports written by either of them or DHHS staff. CA
and PM reported at the time of going back and forth to court for
hearing, etc., Family and Community Services had management
responsibility of report writing.
Foster Care Worker (FCW), through Family and Community
Services, was interviewed on 6/4/23, via telephone. FCW
reported Family and Community Services did not write any court
reports because the case was never adjudicated therefore her
agency never had full jurisdiction/responsibility over the case.
FCW said her agency never received permission to do services
over the case. She said the court order/report came from
Livingston County prosecutor’s office and that’s who wrote the
court order. FCW said the case was in the pre-trial stages and did
not move quickly.
3

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Social work contact dated 4/17/2025, written by FCW that
involved FP, DHHS PM and GAL. FP discussed information
she received that a motion was filed in court to remove Youth
A from her care, and she was upset that an accusation was
made that she was not meeting Youth A’s needs. FCW and
DHHS PM reported to FP that they were unaware of such
motion and reassured FP the agencies were not aware of any
plan to move Youth A from her care
• FP provided the Clinical Review Summary of Youth A, which
noted the denial of services reported by FP. However, this is
not a court report written by foster care workers.
• Motion to disqualify attorney/GAL: Exhibit B-page 2, dated
4/6/2025, stated, the team including GAL and FP discussed
safety planning following discharge from Mott’s UM Hospital.
Areas stated, the hopes are that medication concerns will be
addressed; PHP was offered to FP, but she declined;
Livingston Community Mental Health is actively working to
plan bolstered supports in FP home; and FP has declined
several proposed services. Services were not identified.
Analysis Violation is not established. DHHS did not write or falsify any court
reports to the court, nor did they hold case responsibility. The
clinical review summary does note the decline of services,
however this is not a court report written by foster care to the
courts.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413
Section Medical and dental care policy
Description • (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
• (b) The provision of emergency medical, surgical,
and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A remains hospitalized for 13 days while DHHS failed to
cooperate with his team, causing unnecessary trauma to a child
already in crisis.
Investigation Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on
5/23/2025. FP reported she was not provided needed medical
4

care for Youth A. FP reported Youth A had a meltdown the first
time on 2/28/2025, and she took him to Mott’s UM Hospital. FP
reported the attending physician mentioned to her the possibility of
inpatient care for Youth A but, she expressed explicitly clear to the
attending physician that if inpatient treatment was deemed
necessary, she would fully support that decision. FP reported after
the physician observed Youth A; he determined that inpatient
treatment was not appropriate nor available for Youth A during this
time. No explanation was provided.
FP reported after Youth A broke Youth B’s finger and Youth A put
Youth B’s head through a wall, she took him to his pediatrician for
observation. FP reported after she discussed Youth A’s current
behaviors with Pediatrician and Pediatrician observing Youth A on
3/3/2025, Pediatrician recommended Youth A to be on medication
to control his behaviors and wrote a prescription for the
medications of Clonidine and Concerta. FP reported she and
Youth A’s Pediatrician decided this was an emergency situation
and the prescriptions were filled, and she started giving the
medications to Youth A. FP admitted she was aware that Youth
A’s Birth Father had not signed consent for Youth A to take
psychotropic medications and therefore, she called and reported
the medications to Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) through
Family and Community Services, to get her feedback regarding
administering the medications to Youth A without Birth Father’s
consent. FP reported FCW informed her she would discuss the
situation with her supervisor and get back with her.
FP reported FCW called her and reported she reached out to her
supervisor and was informed to reach out to DHHS as DHHS was
not assigned case management but ultimately had case
responsibility. FP reported FCW informed her Birth Father had
not provided consent for Youth A to take the medication and when
FCW called DHHS to discuss the medication, she was informed
by DHHS Program Manager, since Birth Father had not provided
permission/consent for Youth A to take medications, the
medications had to be stopped until consent from Birth Father was
given. FP reported FCW informed her she would contact Youth
A’s Guardian ad Litem (GAL) to discuss the situation/medications
with her.
FP reported Youth A’s GAL informed her she was going to obtain
a court order for consent to continue Youth A on the medications
he was taking. FP reported the motion to file for consent took time
due to several court hearings and the courts having to hear
testimonies from Youth A’s school, FP, and Youth A’s pediatrician.
5

FP reported after Referee heard the testimonies, a
recommendation to administer the medication to Youth A was
granted on or around 2/10/2025. FP reported on 3/12/2025, an
Emergency Objection and Request for Judicial Review was filed.
She said on 3/21/2025 the Judge presiding over the case denied
Referee’s recommendation for consent and stated the court and
DHHS may not consent to psychotropic medication, and the order
was denied. FP reported it was Livingston County DHHS’s private
attorney on behalf of DHHS who appealed to the medications
being administered to Youth A stating it was against DHHS policy,
and the policy was not followed. FP reported she stopped the
medications abruptly for Youth A.
FP reported Youth A had another meltdown on 3/29/2025 and was
taken to Mott’s UM Hospital ER where he was admitted. FP
reported Youth A, “turned into baby hulk,” and it took several
hospital staff to hold Youth A down and stop him from kicking,
biting, and trying to hurt himself and others. She reported the
same attending physician that worked with Youth A on 2/28/2025,
was in the ER observing Youth A’s behavior. FP reported the
hospital staff administered the same medications to Youth A that
he was on prior from the pediatrician’s office.
FP reported she did not feel Youth A would be safe if he was
discharged from the hospital without the medications and that the
attending physicians agreed with her and stated Youth A was not
going to be released without a court order to consent to Youth A
continuing on the medications provided to him by the hospital.
Chief Administrator (CA) and Program Manager (PM) were
interviewed via TEAM on 5/22/2025. CA repeated the
department did not take case responsibility until 4/23/2025. CA
reported until then the case was managed by a private agency,
Family and Community Services. CA reported DHHS did file an
appeal of Referee’s recommendation of consenting to medication
being administered, as policy for psychotropics medication was
not followed. CA reported DHHS had numerous conversations
with DHHS’s attorney representative and Family and Community
Services FCW. DHHS decided to file the motion. The Judge
agreed with DHHS’s appeal and ordered not to administer the
medications, as Birth Father did not consent. CA reported she
and PM had conversations with the attending physician from
Mott’s UM Hospital, as well as Family and Community Services
FCW, in furtherance of DHHS eventual motion to request
medication.
6

PM reported FP reached out to her on 3/26/2025, because she
was aware that DHHS Attorney was involved in Youth A’s
medications being stopped due to DHHS policy not being followed
and to discuss Youth A’s medication being stopped abruptly by
FP. She reported she informed FP that DHHS employees
involved in the case, including herself, were not medical
professionals and were unable to provide her with medical advice.
PM reported she shared with FP that if FP felt it was an
emergency for Youth A to receive the medications that was
stopped abruptly, to proceed to the nearest emergency room if
care is needed after hours or see a physician during business
hours. PM reported she informed FP to continue to monitor Youth
A for withdrawals or other effects and if these types of behaviors
exist, to take Youth A to the nearest emergency room or call 911.
PM reported DHHS had to appeal the decision of the Referee
because the department did not have a prescribing physician and
a correct diagnosis for Youth A. She reported DHHS reached out
to the physician who worked with Youth A when he went to Mott’s
UM Hospital. PM reported the physician agreed to serve as the
prescribing physician for Youth A on 4/1/2025 as he was familiar
with Youth A’s case.
PM reported DHHS received the court order by the Judge on
4/9/2025 for Youth A’s medication to be administered. PM
reported DHHS had been in contact with legal affairs on the case
extensively. PM provided a breakdown of DHHS’s involvement
with the case and the courts prior to taking responsibility of the
case. She reported DHHS had to file a motion for an appeal of
Referee’s recommendation for the medication to be administered
to Youth A on 2/10/2025. PM reported the administering of the
medication for Youth A was denied on 3/21/2025. PM reported
DHHS filed a motion to consent to medication on 4/3/2025, and
the Judge agreed to the administration of the medication to Youth
A on 4/9/2025. PM reported during this time; Youth A and Youth B
were never removed from FP.
PM reported DHHS opened a special investigation on foster home
on 4/23/2025, when the case was returned back to DHHS
because FP consented to administer psychotropic medication to
Youth A on 2/28/2025, though the emergency no longer existed.
PM reported FP continued to provide this medication to Youth A
without a consent from 2/28/2025 – 3/27/2025. PM reported Birth
Father did not consent and his rights are still intact. PM reported
FP failed to report harm to other children in the home timely and
FP failed to safety plan for early discharge for Youth A from the
7

hospital’s emergency admission on 3/30/2025. PM reported FP
refused partial hospitalization during March’s hospitalization
offered by CMH. PM reported Livingston DHHS requested that
Washtenaw DHHS complete the special investigation.
FCW through Family and Community Services, was
interviewed on 6/4/23, via telephone. She reported the hospital
would not discharge Youth A without medication; therefore, the
hospital was the reason Youth A was in the hospital for 13 days.
She said the attending physician at the hospital felt Youth A
needed to be on medication, and he should not be taken off the
medication drastically and that it would do harm to his body. FCW
said FP was not willing to take Youth A back into her home
without the medications.
FCW reported FP decided this was an emergency situation and
decided on her own to allow Youth A to be prescribed and take
psychotropic medication. FCW reported FP did not discuss the
decision of Youth A taking the medication with her until after he
was prescribed and was taking the medication. FCW reported she
was unaware that it was a psychotropic medication. FCW reported
Birth Father did not consent to psychotropic medication to be
prescribed to Youth A; therefore, the medication had to be
stopped.
FCW reported she contacted the pediatrician’s office to discuss
how to stop the medication without causing harm to Youth A. She
reported she left messages and talked with the receptionist. FCW
said the receptionist said she would deliver the message to
Pediatrician, and Pediatrician would give her a call back. FCW
reported she waited a week and received no call back. FCW
reported her supervisor called the pediatrician’s office on
3/26/2025 and 3/27/2025 and did not receive a response. FCW
reported FP took Youth A off of the medication abruptly. FCW
said Youth A was taken to the pediatrician’s office often for
checkups to make sure he would not suffer any damage due to
being taken off the medication abruptly. She reported the medical
personnel were checking his blood pressure and for any other
potential side effects from no longer taking the medication and
none was found.
Pediatrician was interviewed on 7/21/2025 via telephone. She
reported she is and has been Youth A’s pediatrician since he
entered foster care on July 17, 2022. She reported she completes
Youth A’s well-child examinations, as well as monitoring his
medications. She reported she has had medical appointments
8

with Youth A over twelve times discussing his behaviors with FP.
She reported she first became familiar with Youth A when Birth
Father brought Youth A to her office for a well-being check-up
because Birth Father was allowing FP to be a babysitter for Youth
A and his siblings. She said the medical appointments were
encouraged by FP. Pediatrician reported over the years, Youth
A’s behavior became physically aggressive, and she
recommended he start taking medication on 3/3/2025. She
reported Youth A was out of control and he had started hurting
himself and Youth B. She reported she was unaware Birth Father
had not provided his consent for Youth A to take the medication.
She reported after the medication was discontinued by FP, she
provided regular checkups with Youth A taking his blood work and
monitoring for any side effects. She reported nothing was noted
but, Youth A’s behaviors continued to be inconsistent/aggressive
until FP took him to a hospital emergency department. She
provided no further information.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Pediatric report signed and dated by Pediatrician on 3/3/2025.
The report recommends that Youth A take medication as
prescribed; Concerta in morning, Clonidine in evening, ensure
regular meals and snacks throughout the day, establish
consistent bedtime routine and monitor for side effects.
• Memo from attending Physician dated 3/30/2025. The memo
states:” We are physicians caring for Youth A and are writing
to express our strong recommendation that Youth A should be
placed back on the psychotropic medication regimen. He was
noted to be highly hyperactive, impulsive, and irritable by the
Psychiatry team. In summary, his behavior deteriorated
significantly after stopping psychotropic medications with
imminent harm posed to Youth As foster mother and a sibling
in the home, as well as to himself. He cannot be safely cared
for this time without treating his underlying psychiatric
conditions. Youth A is suffering clear harm and is a safety risk
to himself and others now that we are no longer treating his
established psychiatric conditions, including Attention Deficit
Hyperactivity Disorder -Combined Type and Trauma and
Stressor Related Disorder. The attending Physician strongly
recommend that Youth A be placed back on his home
medications as soon as possible. In the attending physician
professional opinion, withholding these necessary
psychotropic medications places Youth A at risk for immediate
harm, as well as for potentially lifelong impairment.
• Court Order signed 3/11/2025, written by GAL stating, It is
ordered that upon LGAL providing documentation from the
9

pediatrician follow up visit with Youth A to the parties and
courts, DHHS shall consent to psychotropic medication for
Youth A for reasons stated on the record. Medication shall
continue to be administered to Youth A. The required
documentation shall be provided for no less than 14 days.
This court order was denied on 3/21/2025.
• Court Order dated 3/21/2025, Emergency objection and
request per judicial review of referee’s recommendation filed
3/12/2025, request to review the referee's recommendation.
The order states, “DHHS objects to the referee’s
recommendation, which orders DHHS consent to the
administration of psychotropic medications, Clonidine and
Concerta to Youth A based on an emergency exception
contained in the DHHS policy manual and despite his parent’s
objection to the administration of the medication. A child’s
parent must consent to a child’s use of psychotropic
medication for a child in foster care and only if a child’s parent
is unavailable may a party seek consent from the court. In
this case the minor’s parent is available and does not consent
to administration of the psychotropic medication. Therefore,
Petitioners Emergency Objection and Request for Judicial
Review ordering DHHS to consent to administration of
psychotropic medication is granted and the referee’s
recommendation is denied.
• Court Order dated 4/8/2025, Findings of Fact and Referee
Recommendation following Emergency Hearing. The court
order states that the department has proven by clear and
convincing evidence that psychotropic medication is medically
necessary for the treatment of Youth A’s ADHD and Trauma
and stress-related disorder. The Judge finds that the
department has proven by clear and convincing evidence that
the recommended psychotropic medications are in Youth A’s
best interest. The Judge recommends the Court order the
department shall consent to medical treatment for
administration for the administration of psychotropic
medication of Clonidine and Concerta as recommended by his
treating physician. The department presents the testimony of
Mott’s UM Hospital physician and Youth A’s Pediatrician
supporting the use of Clonidine and Concerta is an
emergency and medically necessary for Youth A. The
attending physician is the Director of Child Psychiatry at the
University of Michigan Health System, and he treated Youth A
at Mott UM Children’s Hospital during the two visits Youth A
came to emergency (ER). Pediatrician is Youth A’s long-time
physician since Youth A entered foster care in 2020 and has
10

been working with the Foster Parent and Youth A trying to
assist in controlling his violent behavior.
• DHHS Policy FOM 802-1 Psychotropic medication for youth in
foster care was reviewed. DHHS must follow their policy on
getting informed consent before psychotropic medication is
administered.
• Special Investigation #2025SEC0000555, intake on
4/23/2025, and completed on 7/11/2025, by Washtenaw
DHHS. Recommendation, corrective action plan was
established due to FP administering medication without
having Birth Father consent.
• FCW, social work contact dated 4/9/2025, regarding
psychotropic medication. Youth A was given Zyprexa on
3/30/2025 and 4/1/2025 from Mott’s UM Hospital due to
dysregulation and uncontrollable behavior. FCW received a
court order allowing Youth A to be administered Clonidine and
Zyprexa without Birth Father’s consent as Birth Father was
deemed unable to make an informed decision in the child’s
best interest.
Analysis There is insufficient evidence to support a violation. It is
established by individual interviews, documentation reviewed that
DHHS did not fail to cooperate with Youth A’s team, causing
unnecessary trauma. DHHS did not have case management of
the case until 4/23/2025. It was established that an Emergency
Objection and Request for Judicial Review of Referee’s
recommendation was filed 3/12/25, by DHHS Attorney regarding
administrating psychotropic medication without the consent of the
Birth Father.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section Development of service plans
Description • (1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child,
the child's parents or legal guardian, the referring agency,
and other parties involved in providing needed services or
medical care, unless the agency documents why any of the
entities have not been involved.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation FP reported she has never been involved in Youth A or Youth B’s
development of service plans or the Parent Agency Treatment
Plan.
11

Investigation Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on
5/23/2025. FP reported she is the FP of Youth A and Youth B
who are siblings. She reported Youth A and Youth B have a long
history with her, and they are very bonded. FP reported she has
never been involved in or participated in Youth A or Youth B’s
development of service plans or the Parent Agency Treatment
Plan
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via Team on
5/22/2025. She reported Livingston County Department of Health
and Human Services (DHHS) was not assigned Youth A and
Youth B’s case therefore, DHHS did not write any service plans or
had any contact with FP involving the parent agency treatment
plans.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed via TEAM on
5/22/2025. PM reported the private agency; Family and
Community Services held case management of Youth A and
Youth B; therefore, Family and Community Services had written
all service plans. She reported DHHS did not take responsibility
for Youth A and Youth B’s case until 4/23/2025 when the case
was returned back to the department.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) of Family and Community Services
was interviewed on 6/4/2025, via telephone. FCW reported FP
was involved with all updated Service Plans and Parent Agency
Treatment Plans of Youth A and Youth B. She reported her input,
and concerns were how to control Youth A’s outburst. FCW
reported FP discussed and provided feedback by identifying Youth
A and Youth B’s behaviors. FCW reported Youth A and Youth B
had significant behaviors, however, Youth A’s behaviors were
more physically aggressive than Youth B. FCW reported Youth A
had serious meltdowns and would become physically violent and
attack Youth B. FCW reported FP informed her that Youth A
broke Youth B’s finger and Youth A put Youth B’s head through a
wall.
FCW reported she and FP discussed Youth A receiving a trauma
assessment for his outburst behaviors. FCW reported before
Youth A was registered to receive CMH services for a trauma
assessment, Youth A was suspended from school due to his
aggressive and out of control behaviors. FCW reported she
discussed Youth A’s suspension from school with FP and FP was
infuriated due to having to leave her employment to pick Youth A
up from school again due to him acting out and having outbursts.
12

These behaviors were noted and discussed in Youth A’s treatment
plan with FP as well as in FCW’s social work contacts.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• MiSACWIS Case records of Youth A and Youth B were
reviewed. Youth A, DOB 10/15/2019 and Youth B, DOB
10/18,2020. Youth A and Youth B were placed with FP on
7/8/2020 – 2/15/2022; FP from 2/15/2022 – 9/27/2022; FP
from 9/27/2022 – 5/2/2023; AWOL from 1/3/2025 – 1/6/2025;
FP from 1/6/2025 -3/29/2025; Youth A was in the hospital
from 3/29/2025 -4/10/2025; FP 4/10/2025 – currently placed.
• Initial Service Plan dated 1/3/2025 – 1/28/2025, completed by
FCW from Family and Community Services and signed by
FCW on 1/28/2025 and her supervisor dated 2/11/25. The
report had FP input in the report. The report had the Parent
Agency Treatment Plan that was signed and dated by the FP
that she participated in the development of the service plan.
Each box on the plan was checked by FP and dated
2/20/2025.
• Updated Service Plan dated 1/29/2025 – 4/22/25 dated and
signed by FCW and Supervisor dated 4/22/25. This report
had input from FP, but the report did not have the Parent
Agency Agreement Plan. The case was transferred back to
DHHS who was not responsible for getting the PATP signed
as the department did not write the report.
• Social Work Contact written 3/28/2025, by FCW discussing
services and resources with FP for case planning for Youth A.
Specific resources were not identified.
Analysis Violation is not established. Livingston County DHHS did not hold
case management until 4/23/2025. Interviews with private agency
FCW and documentation reviewed confirm FP’s involvement with
case planning.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
13

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
8/5/2025
____________________________________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
8/8/2025
______________________________________________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
14

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted following allegations by a foster parent that Livingston County DHHS falsified court reports, withheld necessary medical care for a youth, and excluded the foster parent from service planning. The investigation found that DHHS was not managing the case during the period in question, as it was under a private agency's supervision, and thus did not write the contested court reports or service plans. Regarding medical care, DHHS appealed a referee's medication order due to policy requiring birth parent consent, which a judge later upheld, but the subsequent delay in treatment was primarily attributed to hospital discharge protocols and legal processes. Ultimately, no violations of licensing rules were substantiated against the agency.
